definition: to be able to bear/to be able to support
variant of 吃[chi1]
to eat/to consume/to eat at (a cafeteria etc)/to eradicate/to destroy/to absorb/to suffer/to stammer (Taiwan pr. for this sense is [ji2])
to obtain/to get/to gain/to catch (a disease)/proper/suitable/proud/contented/to allow/to permit/ready/finished
structural particle: used after a verb (or adjective as main verb), linking it to following phrase indicating effect, degree, possibility etc
to have to/must/ought to/to need to
to live/to dwell/to stay/to reside/to stop/(suffix indicating firmness, steadiness, or coming to a halt)

sentences.english: My Raft was now strong enough to bear any reasonable Weight;
sentences.chinese: 木排做得相当牢固，也能吃得住相当的重量。

definition: to be unable to bear or support
to be able to endure (exertion, fatigue etc)/to be able to afford
to manage to suppress/to keep under control
to refrain/to be able to endure it
a couple of times/to repeat the same/the same old trick/tricks of the trade
to have real skill/to know one's stuff
luckily/fortunately
susceptible to force but not persuasion
can bow and submit, or can stand tall (idiom, from Book of Changes); ready to give and take/flexible
to be popular/to be getting on well/much in demand
erhua variant of 身板[shen1 ban3]
reliable/secure/stable/firm
(coll.) not bad/good/fine
lit. can pass through (an opening)/fig. can get by (in life)/tolerably well/not too bad/How are you getting by?/How's life?
unbearable/terrible/enough/unlikely
soft skin and tender flesh (idiom)/smooth-skinned
